facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 79 of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 79 of 1971.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from Judgment and Order dated 16th January 1971 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1168 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated 16th January 1-971 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1168 of 1968.

facts.text: Appellant aged 23 was arrested on 9-4-1967 by Railway Police at Bombay Central Railway Station.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant aged 23 was arrested on 9-4-1967 by the Railway Police at the Bombay Central Railway Station

facts.text: Appellant was hurriedly trying to get into a second class compartment of the Frontier Mail bound for Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: as he was hurriedly trying to get into a second class companypartment of the Frontier Mail bound for Delhi.

facts.text: Appellant's manner aroused suspicion despite having a ticket, leading to detention.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that manner in which he was trying to enter the second class companypartment and his nervourness on being questioned by a Railway C.I.D. Police Officer, although the appellant had a ticket on him, aroused suspicion so that the appellant was detained.

facts.text: On search at Police Station in presence of Panchas, nine bars of gold with foreign markings found secreted in concealed pockets of appellant's trousers.

anchor.surface_text: On a search of his person at the Police Station in the presence of Panchas, nine bars of gold with foreign markings were found secreted in especially made companycealed pockets of his trousers.

facts.text: Gold bars seized by Railway Police.

anchor.surface_text: These were seized by the Railway Police.

facts.text: Appellant's statement under section 108 of Customs Act recorded on 10-4-67 before Shri L. A. Digama, Additional Chief Inspector of Customs, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: After further questioning by the Police, the appellant was summoned before Shri L. A. Digama, Addi- tional Chief Inspector of Customs, Bombay, where his statement under section 108 of the-Customs Act 1962 was recorded on 10-4-67.

facts.text: In statement, appellant admitted recovery of gold bars from his person.

anchor.surface_text: In that statement, the appellant admitted the recovery of gold bars from his person

facts.text: Appellant agreed with Pannalal to carry gold bars to Delhi for Rs. 100 payment.

anchor.surface_text: and stated that he had agreed with one Pannalal to carry them for delivery at Delhi for a sum of Rs. 100 to be paid to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant knew he was carrying gold from Pannalal's information and weight of bars.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that, from what Pannalal had told him and also from the weight of the bars, he knew that he was carrying gold.

facts.text: Appellant's father was with him but nothing incriminating recovered, so released.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that his father was also with him, but, as numberhing incriminating was recovered from the father, he was allowed to go away.

facts.text: Appellant admitted knowing transporting gold like this was a criminal offence.

anchor.surface_text: He also admitted that he knew that transporting of Old like this was a criminal offence.

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted and convicted by Presidency Magistrate of Bombay under section 135(b) of Customs Act 1962, sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was prosecuted and companyvicted by the Presidency Magistrate of Bombay under section 135 b  of the Customs Act of 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and sentenced to three months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant acquitted of charges under Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Charges under the Defence, of India Rules were also preferred against him but he was acquitted of these.

facts.text: High Court of Bombay affirmed conviction and sentence after re-examining evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay after carefully re-examining the whole evidence in the case, had affirmed the companyviction and sentence of the appellant

facts.text: Special leave to appeal obtained to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: but, the appellant bad obtained special leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Gold valued at about Rs. 40,000 with Rs. 17,000 duty payable.

anchor.surface_text: It is incredible that any person would entrust gold valued at about Rs. 40,000, on which Rs. 17,000 was payable as duty alone,

facts.text: Appellant carrying gold from Bombay to Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the appellant was found carrying gold from Bombay, a port of entry for smuggled goods, to Delhi, where there is a good market for gold.

facts.text: Supreme Court reduces sentence to period already undergone, dismisses appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the age of the appellant and the fact that there is numberprevious companyviction proved against him, we companysider it to be undesirable to send the appellant back to jail for a few days. We, therefore, reduce the sentence to the period already undergone. Subject to this modification, this appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant on bail, need not surrender.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is on bail, need number surrender.

arguments.claim: Offence under s135(b) punishable even without direct proof of import if offender acquires possession or concerned in carrying goods known or believed liable to confiscation under s111

anchor.surface_text: Apart from other reasons given below, we think that this argument overlooks that an offence under section. 135 1   b  is punishable if the offender acquires possession of or is in any way companycerned in carrying removing, depositing, harboring, keeping, companycealing, selling or purchasing or in any other manner dealing with any goods which he knows or has reason to believe are liable to companyfiscation under section Ill.

arguments.claim: High Court and Magistrate relied on circumstantial evidence of gold's character and accused's knowledge, not s123 presumption

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the High Court or the Magistrate had used this presumption. We find that they had relied upon circumstantial evidence in the case to infer the character of the gold recovered and the accuseds guilty knowledge.

arguments.claim: Conduct of accused and incredible version sufficient for knowledge of smuggled character per Issardas Daulat Ram precedent

anchor.surface_text: A reference to Issardas Daulat Ram Ors. V. Union of India Ors.  1  is enough to show that the companyduct of the accused and the incredible version set up by him were enough to saddle the accused with the necessary knowledge of the character of the goods found in his possession.

arguments.claim: Appellant's story of being entrusted gold worth Rs40,000 by stranger Pannalal for Rs100 incredible

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, we have number only evidence of the suspicious companyduct of the appellant but his own admission that he knew that it was an offence to carry the gold which he had been asked to transport for payment of money to him. He had put forward an incredible story of having been entrusted with so much gold by one Pannalal

arguments.claim: Circumstances raise presumption under s114 Evidence Act of illegal import covered by s111(d); burden under s106 on appellant to prove innocent receipt

anchor.surface_text: Atleast, the burden of proving an innocent receipt of gold lay upon the appellant under Section 106 Evidence Act. The totality of facts proved was enough, in our opinion, to raise a presumption under section 114 Evidence Act that the gold had been illegally imported into the companyntry

arguments.claim: Suspicious carriage from Bombay port of entry to Delhi gold market indicates recent smuggling

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the appellant was found carrying gold from Bombay, a port of entry for smuggled goods, to Delhi, where there is a good market for gold. If it was number recently smuggled gold carried companytrary to law there was numberneed for the clandestine and guilty manner of transporting it.

holdings.text: An offence under section 135(b) of the Customs Act is punishable if the offender acquires possession of or is in any way concerned in carrying, removing, depositing, harboring, keeping, concealing, selling or purchasing or in any other manner dealing with any goods which he knows or has reason to believe are liable to confiscation under section 111.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from other reasons given below, we think that this argument overlooks that an offence under section. 135 1   b  is punishable if the offender acquires possession of or is in any way companycerned in carrying removing, depositing, harboring, keeping, companycealing, selling or purchasing or in any other manner dealing with any goods which he knows or has reason to believe are liable to companyfiscation under section Ill.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's argument requiring direct evidence of import overlooked; s135(b) punishes based on knowledge of liability to confiscation under s111, supported by circumstantial evidence.

holdings.text: The High Court and Magistrate did not use the presumption under section 123 of the Customs Act but relied on circumstantial evidence to infer the smuggled character of the gold and the accused's guilty knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the High Court or the Magistrate had used this presumption. We find that they had relied upon circumstantial evidence in the case to infer the character of the gold recovered and the accuseds guilty knowledge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even applying Gian Chand, no presumption invoked; courts used conduct and incredible defence per Issardas precedent; result unchanged.

holdings.text: Circumstances permit inference that the gold was recently imported into India after 1948 restrictions, making it liable to confiscation under section 111(d).

anchor.surface_text: We think that, in the circumstances of the case, an inference companyld very well be made that the gold must have been recently imported into the companyntry, or, at any rate, after the law passed in 1948 restricting its entry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious conduct, clandestine transport from Bombay port to Delhi market, foreign markings, incredible story indicate recent smuggling; appellant's admission of offence confirms.

holdings.text: The totality of proved facts raises a presumption under section 114 of the Evidence Act that the gold was illegally imported, covered by section 111(d) of the Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: The totality of facts proved was enough, in our opinion, to raise a presumption under section 114 Evidence Act that the gold had been illegally imported into the companyntry

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial evidence including conduct, value, transport route, and lack of explanation suffice for presumption of illegal import.

holdings.text: Burden of proving innocent receipt of gold lay on the appellant under section 106 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Atleast, the burden of proving an innocent receipt of gold lay upon the appellant under Section 106 Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of possession and knowledge especially within accused's knowledge; no proof of Pannalal or innocent entrustment.

holdings.text: No injustice suffered by appellant due to form of questions under section 342 CrPC; fully aware of case, no prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: But, we are unable to hold that the appellant suffered any injustice for this reason. Indeed, he had number even raised such a question in the Trial Court or before the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant gave detailed s108 statement, filed written explanation; knew allegations; objection technical, not raised earlier, curable.

holdings.text: Sentence reduced to period already undergone given appellant's young age and lack of prior conviction; appeal dismissed subject to modification.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the age of the appellant and the fact that there is numberprevious companyviction proved against him, we companysider it to be undesirable to send the appellant back to jail for a few days. We, therefore, reduce the sentence to the period already undergone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality considering youth, no priors, time served; no need for further jail.
